subject: HwmonTempSensor: Add BMCOnDieThermalSensor type
commitMessage:
HwmonTempSensor: Add BMCOnDieThermalSensor type

Now we add new sensor type BMCOnDieThermalSensor in HWmon temperatue
sensors to support thermal sensors. User need to define thermal sensor
in thermal zone in DTS.
To identify each thermal sensor per each zone, we use "Index" to match
them. User can refer following example to add BMCOnDieThermalSensor into
HWmon temperature sensor.

Example:

Entity manager configuration =>
        {
            "Index": "0",
            "Name": "BMC_CPU_Temp0",
            "Thresholds": [
...
            ],
            "Type": "BMCOnDieThermalSensor"
        },
        {
            "Index": "1",
            "Name": "BMC_CPU_Temp1",
...
            "Type": "BMCOnDieThermalSensor"
        },

root@evb-npcm845:~# busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.HwmonTempSensor
└─/xyz
  └─/xyz/openbmc_project
    └─/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors
      └─/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature
        ├─/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/BMC_CPU_Temp0
        ├─/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/BMC_CPU_Temp1
        └─ ...

Signed-off-by: Brian Ma <chma0@nuvoton.com>
Change-Id: I9a7c996a17dfdab257bb83cfea5122e7857aeab8

Only need this when there is no hyphen, i.e. findHyphen == std::string::npos
Done
wrap your commit 50/72 please.
Done
Considering we know at compile time which bmc we're on, and I would expect this to apply to ALL nuvoton BMCs, does this need to have some kind of different file with a probe statement?

Not all Nuvoton BMCs support this kind on die thermal sensor, now we only support it on npcm8xx serials. And user can adjust their threshold, pid configuration easier when we export this sensor as hwmon thermal sensor in dbus sensors.

My point is still the same, we know we're on an npcm8xx at compile time.  I never said to remove their thresholds or PID loops, I just said to move them to another file, with a probe that was based on the chip we're compiling for, given that they will be common across all BMC systems.
Seems reasonable.  Can you push that commit somewhere so that I can see the full content?
your commit above says this DOESN'T have a bus and address, so your commit should support these parameters not being present.
The idea use the bus and address is for lesser code change. User can use bus 0 and address x to present each thermal zones.

> The idea use the bus and address is for lesser code change.

Smaller code changes is not a design goal with entity-manager, as is documented in the repo.  These files have design principals that are documented in the EM repo and are in opposition to this.  Please read, understand, and follow them.

> User can use bus 0 and address x to present each thermal zones.

Considering that the user in this case has no control over what thermal sensors each piece of silicon has, I would not expect that to be controllable through the config file, only the thresholds and scan rates would be configurable.
Thanks for your suggestion. The bus and address is removed, and I add index to identify each sensor.
Please come up with a more appropriate typename for this.  Off the top of my head, maybe BMCOnDieThermalSensor

Yes, the name thermal zone is not quite intuitive to know what it is.
But just like other thermal sensors, the name comes from kernel. It makes sense user can map configuration type name and kernel sysfs device name.

> Yes, the name thermal zone is not quite intuitive to know what it is.
> But just like other thermal sensors, the name comes from kernel.

There are thermal sensors that don't do this, and this is definitely not a "rule", in fact, it's documented as the opposite.  The ones that are common to the kernel use the same name because that is the part number, which the kernel also uses.

> It makes sense user can map configuration type name and kernel sysfs device name.

Please don't.  There should be nothing linux specific in these config files.  If you wanted to put this under the specific BMC part number, that might be fine, but considering that we know the BMC type at compile time, it seems like we could have a common config for it, unless there's going to be BMC-model-specific parameters we might need to set.
The name BMCOnDieThermalSensor seems more common for all BMC.

Thanks for Ed's suggestion, I move the thermal zone to a stand along entity manager configuration with a probe function for npcm8xx serial BMC. And also change the configuration name to BMCOnDieThermalSensor, use index to replace bus and address to avoid misunderstanding.
Index is an improvement, but it's not very descriptive for a user.  How does a user know what to put into "Index" in these cases?  Would they ever set a threshold differently per index?
update commit message and add Index description.

nit, I think this sentence can be removed.  Just describe what the sensor is used for.  There's no need to compare to other sensors, especially when the comparison is confusing (ie, this is nothing like a pmbus hwmon sensor).
Done
I don't think this is true anymore?
Done
You've added this previously unknown field with no description.  How does a user know what to put here?  Please answer in your commit message.
Done

thermal_zone0 is a linux naming convention?  What does "thermal_zoneN" convey in terms of the hardware?  Are there reasons why I user would set different thermal parameters for each zone?  For that matter, is there a reason a user would set different BMC thermal parameters for a given system?  I assume that a given BMC model (that we know at compile time) would have a known thermal threshold.

More details here would be great.

Now we only use thermal zone to monitor BMC CPU themperature, but the thermal zone may be used for other on DIE thermal sensors. I even think we may not need two thermal (zone) sensors in the BMC, but I think it may be an example for configure mutiple thermal_zone type sensors with BMCOnDieThermalSensor.
Ack

This doesn't really answer my question though.  "thermal zone" is a linux naming convention, which we explicitly try to avoid in config files, and also has problematic naming because of the fact that "thermal zone" could also mean the zones we use to configure fans.  What I'm trying to understand is:

1. Do these thermal zones need to be configurable per-platform?  Or are they determined by the SOC?
2. If yes, how would a user determine how many "thermal zones" they need or want?
3. Is any of this auto-detectable based on the SOC (aspeed, nuvoton, ect) we're using, so we can have reasonable defaults for users that don't configure these thermal zones?

1. Users can configure DTS to determine how many thermal zone they need.
The thermal zone may not only contains BMC CPU thermal sensor.
For example user can set DTS like: thermal zone 0 i2c temperature sensor to monitor board temperture, thermal zone 1 monitor CPU temp
I think it should be configurable per-platform.

2. It's all depend on platfrom design

3. This change purpose is export CPU temperture from sysfs to Openbmc applications.
And the Kernel thermal framework make thermal sysfs under thermal zones. The "zones" may contain cool device, or not. It depend on platform. Users can configure their fan control by phosphor pid or thermal zone. No matter what they choose, they still need a way to read thermal sensor data.

> 1. Users can configure DTS to determine how many thermal zone they need.
> The thermal zone may not only contains BMC CPU thermal sensor.
> For example user can set DTS like: thermal zone 0 i2c temperature sensor to monitor board temperture, thermal zone 1 monitor CPU temp
> I think it should be configurable per-platform.

We already have configuration items for thermal zones and thermal controllers.  How is this different than what exists already?

> 
> 2. It's all depend on platfrom design

So a thermal zone is for multiple sensors?  How would a "platform design" determine how many they want?  Why would they use a thermal zone over the existing mechanisms for aggregating?

> 
> 3. This change purpose is export CPU temperture from sysfs to Openbmc applications.

There are already several examples of exporting CPU temperatures from sysfs, generally using hwmontempsensor or cpusensor.  Why do we need a new one?

> And the Kernel thermal framework make thermal sysfs under thermal zones. The "zones" may contain cool device, or not. It depend on platform. Users can configure their fan control by phosphor pid or thermal zone. No matter what they choose, they still need a way to read thermal sensor data.

We still need a description of why this is different and needed compared to the existing thermal zones.  We're currently doing thermal control in userspace, which currently doesn't require the kernel.


Ideally all of the above questions would be answered in your commit message, along with background.

update commit message
In the thermal framework design, you can set multiple sensor in a zone to descript the "hotspot", but sysfs only show one temperature.
The hwmontempsensor device architecture is most like thermal sysfs, so we choose use it.

> update commit message
> In the thermal framework design, you can set multiple sensor in a zone to descript the "hotspot", but sysfs only show one temperature.

By that description, entity-manager already has an implementation of that, called "Zone" in the config files.  You haven't really enumerated how this is different, or why we need another one.

For that matter, there is also phosphor margin temp, which is a second way in the project (not something I'd recommend though) for doing this same thing.

> The hwmontempsensor device architecture is most like thermal sysfs, so we choose use it.

You still haven't enumerated why someone would choose to use it over the existing solutions.
Update commit message
Since rest of list is arranged alphabetically can we move this to top?
Done

This is essentially duplicating features (thresholding, hysteresis, thermal zones, poll times, ect) that we have already in userspace.  The commit message needs to identify:
1. Why this is needed over the existing solutions.
2. When a user would pick one solution over another.

I really suspect this is completely duplicating functionality, which, might be better than what we have, but if it's better, we should plan on a full transition, and removing the userspace thresholding code entirely for hwmon sensors.
Questions still unanswered.
Yes, the thermal zone may be duplicating functionality with user space application. But the user space application is more flexible, we can change the policy even runtime.
So, if the userspace application is more flexible, why would we use the kernel solution.
Entity-manager configs should not require referencing the DTS.  They should be buildable by engineers with only access to the board schematic.
this just provide the example how the thermal zone index come from.
Your response doesn't answer the question.  Yes, this is an example, but given that "Index" doesn't represent anything physical in this case, it generally would not go in an EM config file.

This doesn't really seem right either.  If we know at compile time, we don't need a per-hardware config at all, and we can just enable the feature at compile time.

If users do as this suggests, the BMC is going to show up in the system as a FRU, which isn't really what we want.
Remove this comment, BMC model is know at compile time. But DTB may changed at boot time.
EM configs should have no reference to DTS/DTB

I'm starting to wonder if doing a design doc would be a good idea here.  it doesn't need to be extensive, but has a lot of template questions for the information I'm asking for that might help guide you for what's being asked.  I don't necessarily want to impose more work, but the more responses I get to this, the more it seems like this is just duplicating function that exists in a couple places already, that we arguably shouldn't be duplicating.  I'm happy to be convinced that we need this over the existing solutions, but to do that, we need some kind of statement about what the existing solutions can't do, and why adding this dependency on the kernel thresholding and margining system is beneficial to us.
